definition: this/these/(commonly pr. [zhei4] before a classifier, esp. in Beijing)
disposition of troops/wave/spate/burst/spell/short period of time/classifier for events or states of short duration

son/child/seed/egg/small thing/1st earthly branch: 11 p.m.-1 a.m., midnight, 11th solar month (7th December to 5th January), year of the Rat/Viscount, fourth of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/ancient Chinese compass point: 0° (north)

sentences.english: I always play mahjong at Guo's house.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子我老是去老郭家打牌。

sentences.english: I have more time to think these days, Jeff…I'm proud of you.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子我有更多的时间想些事情，杰夫，我为你自豪。

sentences.english: No, good jobs are not so easy to come by these days.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子不太容易找到好的工作。

sentences.english: His veins had swelled with the effort of the cough, and the varicose ulcer had started itching.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子咳嗽，直叫他静脉贲张，脚脖子也刺痒起来。

sentences.english: All the relevant food safety reports, shocking ah.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子有关食品安全的报道篇篇触目惊心啊。

sentences.english: You look much slimmer these days!
sentences.chinese: 你这阵子看起来苗条多了。

sentences.english: We all give supports to Sichuan.
sentences.chinese: 这阵子，全世界都在支持四川。

sentences.english: Indian children these days seem to be leaning towards western ways too.
sentences.chinese: 印度孩子，这阵子似乎倾向于西方的方式。

definition: lit. twice every three days (idiom); practically every day/frequently
to rush/in a hurry/to worry about being late
in a moment/later/also pr. [dai1 hui3 r5] or [dai1 hui5 r5]
lit. badly burned about the head (from trying to put out a fire) (idiom)/fig. hard-pressed/under pressure (from a heavy workload, creditors etc)
